thread.title: Richard Gere gives insight into homelessness
thread.title_full: Richard Gere gives insight into homelessness | Boston Herald

author: Stephen Schaefer
title: Richard Gere gives insight into homelessness
text:
“Time Out of Mind” begins simply as Richard Gere’s George Hammond is rousted out of a derelict apartment and sent into the streets.
You’re immediately aware of the surrounding sounds — of sirens, horns, a babble of indistinct voices­ — that never, ever stop in Oren Moverman’s (“The Messenger”) immensely moving, documentary-like portrait of this man.
Filmed entirely on Manhattan locations, “Time” doesn’t impose the usual dramatic structure in which Hammond is expected to have a goal.
Yet Moverman, working from his own screenplay, lets us see there’s a life here and captures its extremes.
Hammond is, for all purposes, invisible to passers-by — except when he’s a target for random violence.
When he lines up for a bed in a New York City homeless shelter, he finds he must be interviewed and documented into the system. He struggles with a social worker to recount a blurred, better forgotten history.
Outside the shelter one morning, he wakes from under a blanket to see prep school kids taking his picture, as if he’s an exotic creature.
Hammond may be damaged, but he knows who his daughter (Jena Ma­lone) is and that she works in a Soho bar.
Gere’s low-key efforts work, especially when seducing an old acquaintance (Kyra Sedgwick) now homeless or reaching out to his estranged daughter.
Ultimately, this is a haunting look at a life, like many, very much on the edge.
(“Time Out of Mind” includes sexual situations.)
